intro: Carpesium erythrolepis, commonly known as the red-leaf beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in a head, typical of the daisy family. Its fruits are prickly, dry capsules that contain several seeds, aiding in seed dispersal. Carpesium erythrolepis is often found in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
